text.p: Here are highlights of stories reported by Hungary's press, based on information by Nepszabadsag's Hungary Around the Clock service. For further details on how to subscribe to Hungary Around the Clock, please contact Monica Kovacs at (361) 351 7142 or fax your request to (361) 351 7141.
***GENERAL***
ALL PAPERS
- Hungary's air force will be set up as a separate branch of the military.
- The government approved a deal between Hungary and the WTO on agricultural export subsidies.
- Hungary will meet EU environmental regulations before 2002.
- Opposition Christian Democrat party is expected to expell another two of its members.
- The Finance Ministry plans to introduce student loans of up to 260,000 forints per student over a four-year study period.
- Industry and Trade Minister Szabolcs Fazakas goes to Moscow on July 28.
***BUSINESS***
ALL PAPERS
- Standard & Poor's has reaffirmed itts BBB plus rating for Hungary's long-term foreign debt.
- June household savings doubled to 3,000 billion forints from last June.
- ELMKA motorway operator would be ready to lower tarrifs on a motorway stretch oif it will be allowed to collect fees on the entire length of the respective motorway.
- Heationg prices in Budapest will rise 10.7 percent in September.
- National electricity company MVM published two tenders of a total $2.5 billion for a total capacity increase of 800 megawats.
- Privatisation agency APV Rt has eased the tender terms for Diosgyor steel works.
VILAGGAZDASAG
- Aral Hungary sees 50 filling stations by year-end.
-- Budapest newsroom +36 1 327-4040
